description: This is a guided walking tour of historic locations for the 2SLGBTQAI+ community in Windsor-Essex, Ontario. It is an implementation of the open-source Pytheas application, written in Typescript using the React, Emotion, Jotai, and Leaflet libraries, and the OpenRouteService API.

I was the lead developer on Queer Walk, working from May to August 2023 alongside Haley Tibbitts and our project manager Zhenia Tomé, with funding and support from Parallel 42 Systems and Windsor Hackforge. The research and organizing for the tour was provided by Walter Cassidy of the Windsor-Essex Rainbow Alliance.

The Pytheas application itself is based on work originally developed for the McDougall Corridor tour application, built in partnership with the Essex County Black Historical Research Society, the Windsor Law Centre for Cities, the School of Creative Arts (SOCA), and Leddy Library, with funding provided by Canada's federal government through the Canadian Urban Institute. The development of this implementation resulted in several significant functional upgrades to the open-source code base.

This is a web application for storing short text notes to revisit later, written in Typescript and SASS using the Angular framework. The user can save up to 12 notes between 1-85 characters in length, each in the colour of their choice (pink, purple, green, or yellow). The site has a background decorated in pigeons, and offers both light and dark themes. Using the Angular local storage API, all data is saved client-side so the notes and selected theme are persistent until the browser cache is cleared. I built it over a weekend in February 2023.

This is a statistics-based card game that I originally built in October and November 2022 during my time at Juno College, written in JavaScript and CSS using the React library. The site uses a data set of superhero character objects stored in Firebase, each with statistics pulled from the Marvel Database Wiki.

On game start, the character objects are retrieved, shuffled, and dealt into 2 decks of 10 cards each—one for you (the player) and one for your opponent (the computer). Each round, you choose the statistic from your card that you believe to be larger than your opponent's, and the winner of the challenge gets both cards. Game play continues until one of the decks is empty.

This is an application for viewing images of pigeons in different cities around the world. It is written in HTML, jQuery, and CSS, uses the Flickr API, and was originally built in July 2022 during my time at Juno College. The site retrieves JSON data objects representing photos of pigeons, either in the user's selected city or in a random city, it shuffles through those image objects, and then it displays one of the photos on the page.
This is a website for Sydney Gautreau's editing and writing coaching business, written in HTML, JavaScript, and SASS, and originally built in November 2022.
